message_1: There are 40 students in a math club. 20 students play chess, 25 students play board games, and 15 students play both games. How many students in the math club don't play either game?
message_2:
Let A be the number of students who play chess, B be the number of students who play board games, and C be the number of students who play both games. We are given:

A = 20
B = 25
C = 15

We want to find the number of students who don't play either game. To do this, we can use the principle of inclusion-exclusion:

Total number of students = (Number of students who play chess) + (Number of students who play board games) - (Number of students who play both games) + (Number of students who don't play either game)

40 = 20 + 25 - 15 + (Number of students who don't play either game)

Now, we can solve for the number of students who don't play either game:

40 = 30 + (Number of students who don't play either game)

(Number of students who don't play either game) = 40 - 30

(Number of students who don't play either game) = 10

So, there are 10 students in the math club who don't play either game.
